unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Margin of Error
question_text: The margin of error of a confidence interval increases as the
solution:
Consider the basic formula for the margin of error, which is:

$$z^{*}\cdot \left(\dfrac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\right)$$

If the confidence level increases, then the $z^{*}$ value will be larger. Thus the margin of error will get larger.

Note that any confidence interval formula, not just the example used in this explanation, would yield the same answer.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A'and 'C' are incorrect; these have nothing to do with the value of the margin of error.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; an increase in the sample size yields a decrease of the margin of error (division by a larger $\sqrt{n}$ value makes the fraction $\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$ get smaller).

Choice 'D' is incorrect; an decrease in the standard error $\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$ results in an decrease in the margin of error of the confidence interval.
